DOC.HEAD: Weekend Freeze Leaves Florida Crop Damaged
Eds: SUBS 2nd graf pvs, `This freeze ..., with one graf to show Collier County has more winter vegetables than citrus. Picks up 3rd graf pvs, In Texas ...
DOC.TEXT: The frigid weather that swept through much of the South over the holiday weekend has caused substantial damage to Florida's $3.5 billion citrus crop and hurt other important winter crops, agriculture officials say. ``This freeze has just devastated us,'' said Anne Goodnight, commissioner in Collier County, which has many winter vegetable crops and some citrus. She said she planned to ask Gov. Bob Martinez for disaster aid this week. In Texas, state officials estimate 70 percent of the citrus crop and 80 percent of the winter vegetable crop were destroyed when temperatures plunged into the low 20s and upper teens. Losses there were estimated at $200 million. But some Texas officials and growers predicted they would be higher because warming temperatures ruined any hopes of salvaging the frozen fruit for juice. Although Florida officials haven't released actual production losses, the freeze damage is likely to be substantial since much of the state's crop was still on the trees when temperatures dipped blow freezing starting on Saturday. The plunging temperatures taxed the state's utilities over the weekend and again today. The power companies tried to divide the misery by cutting electricity to different areas for short periods of time, but the moves wreaked havoc on citrus groves. Most growers abandoned traditional methods of protecting their crops, such as using smudge pots or wind machines, and instead used networks of microjets, which spray water on the trees to protect them from freezing. When the power went off, the protective irrigation systems failed. ``There was nothing I could do about it,'' said John Heist, a Lake County citrus grower. ``They turned off the electricity at about 9 a.m. (Sunday). But it was too cold and the system froze in parts.'' ``We would have been better off not to turn on the system at all.'' Immokalee, a winter vegetable production center, was hit hard by the chill. Farmers said the area lost more than 90 percent of its tomatoes, peppers and other vegetables, which are worth more than $200 million yearly. Among the few happy farmers were strawberry growers who came through the hard freeze better than others. ``No wind, no problem,'' said Roy Parke of Parkesdale Farms, a berry farmer in Plant City. A lack of wind allows irrigation systems to build an even layer of ice on fragile plants to protect the bloom. Wind scatters the water from sprinklers, allowing colder temperatures to get to the plants and damage or kill them. Parke estimated that the $162 million berry industry likely would suffer only half the loss expected. Growers were not the only agricultural workers suffering from the freeze. Migrant workers found their livelihood endangered. ``If there aren't any other crops to pick, these people don't have any other place to work,'' said Charles Esposito, program manager for the Beth-El Mission in Plant City. More than 10,000 migrant workers living in Immokalee for the picking season, which runs from November through May, may be unemployed. Before the freeze, they earned $40 to $125 a day.
